awd_titl_txt: CyberCorps: Scholarship for Service to Create Community Cyber Security Champions (CCSC) and a Collaborative Learning Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to establish a new CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at St. Cloud State University (SCSU) to prepare highly-qualified Cybersecurity professionals for entry into the federal, state, local, and tribal government workforce.

St. Cloud State University (SCSU) has an undergraduate program in Information Technology Security (ITS) and a Master's of Science in Information Assurance (MSIA), both of which are undergoing strong growth. The proposed CyberCorps®: SFS program will create Community Cyber Security Champions (CCSC) and a Collaborative Learning Environment. St. Cloud State University has been designated as a National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education since 2009. ITS and MSIA students have solid theoretical foundation, along with experiential learning opportunities throughout the curriculum. They have participated in the Collegiate Cyber Defense competition since 2007, won the state competition twice, and the Midwest Regional competition once. In addition, they also won the national Open Web Application Security project - Application Security competition in 2011. The proposed project has a strong management plan, including student selection, mentoring, and assessment. CyberCorps students will form a team of cybersecurity champions leading an effort to educate the broader public.

The main goal of the project is to attract, retain and graduate high quality students with knowledge and skills necessary to join government cybersecurity workforce. Another goal of the project is to attract female students by exposing them to cybersecurity aspects that have direct social impact. It will be accomplished by implementing community service component, where scholarship recipients will educate the broader community. This social part of the project may attract more female students and will benefit the community as a whole. The student clubs will regularly organize community events to educate the public on cyber threats and how to mitigate them. The project involves two Minnesota Community Colleges: Century College in St. Paul and Lake Superior College in Duluth. The project will also recruit from Lincoln University in Missouri, an HBCU, and other minority serving institutions. Scholarship recipients will form collaborative study groups involving students from SCSU and the two Community Colleges to share knowledge and experience with cyber defense practice.

por.por_cntn:
The project resulted in positive impacts at several scopes and levels. The project prepared and graduated numerous students who filled vital cybersecurity positions at the local, the state and the national levels.  Those graduates were proven to have competencies, skills and experiences needed to meet the demands and the challenges of protecting our cyber systems and environment at times when changes in the field are getting faster by the day. As we reviewed and assessed applicants to the program, we emphasized factoring in how the applicants’ willing to serve outweighed their valuation financial benefits from the program.  Therefore, the greatest majority of the scholars in the project honored their commitment and managed to secure jobs with government agencies despite the financial attraction from the private sector.  The grant supported a total of 31 scholars. Only two students withdrew, which represented a high level of retention. Additionally, 4 non-scholars students were supported through developing the online cybersecurity educational modules and another 4 women students were supported to attend professional conferences.  

 

It would be a mistake not to refer here to a secondary but a very important outcome of the project that will have a wider and longer impact on how to prepare students in STEM education in general and computing/cyber education in particular. To make sure our scholars are fully prepared to serve our nation and meet our societal needs.  We reevaluated our mission, vision and guiding principles to reflect the new role and the value proposition of higher education in the society of the 21st Century. Hence, we strategically planned and implemented initiatives for:

  • Continuing improvement through consulting with industrial partners to build the needed skillful workforce that would assure the competitiveness of the University graduates and our industry. For that objective, we developed the concept of Preparedness for Successful Career and Citizenship Maps and implemented it for the computing programs and expanded them in all programs in the College of Science and Engineering at Saint Cloud State University. The maps guide students, and advisors on where, when and how the students will build competency in foundational knowledge, most recent technical skills, methods and tools, life-long abilities and soft skills. It would also help faculty and academic planners to integrate liberal education into the curriculum. The maps included co-curricular activities that are integral to meeting all elements of student preparedness.  The Cybersecurity program success map is attached.
  • Utilizing synergic academia/industry/government partnerships for the socio-cultural-economic development and enrichment of the region, State, and beyond.

 

During our last phase of the project we aimed designing a virtual lab architecture capable of potentially providing students with a hands-on learning experience in support of an online educational offering. We identified alternative approaches to designing a virtual lab and address the criteria for selecting the optimal deployment method. Virtualization offers a significant instructional advantage in delivering a cost-effective and flexible, hands-on learning experience. This project resulted in developing educational and hands-on laboratory exercises for computer and information security education. The Labs were published on a website and a YouTube Channel. Both are available publically to high school teachers and students:

  • Website - https://cybersecurity-scsu.net/
  • YouTube Channel - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQN7yBFT6JyOVpyojpLTVkQ/featured

St. Cloud State University will use the concept of the virtual lab architecture in the delivery of courses to non-traditional groups of students who usually tend to study through remote education methods. Additionally, SCSU will utilize the concept to create and deliver K-12 teacher workshops and student camps. These workshops and camps will become very beneficial for students and teachers from underserved communities in Minnesota.  According to the U.S. Census, Minnesota has experienced one of the most profound changes in demographics over the past three census periods. Specifically, the ' 'state's population has moved from 5.6% persons of color in 1990 to 14.7% as of 2010. Between 2008 and 2018, the proportion of ' 'Minnesota's school children of color has moved from 24% to an overall rate of 34%. Of the 10,271 students in St. Cloud Area School District in 2021, 53% are students of color, and 23% are English learners. The STEM Education director at SCSU and PI of the NSF-Noyce Husky STEM Teacher-Scholar program has developed a partnership with school districts to offer alternative summer school programming for middle grades English-learners. The program utilizes coding as the foundation to interest students in computing-related careers and strengthens their basic English and mathematics literacy skills. This partnership allowed the NSF-Cyber Corp program to pilot the virtual labs for Cyber Security Education either through after-school programs or camps for middle and high school students in the St. Cloud district who are participants in the alternative skill development programming.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Adel Ali
